There is emerging doubt about the successful delivery of the scheme.   At the time of completing this form (mid-July) we have received informal advice from Transport for London that the scheme costs have increased by £40m and that TfL is considering options which include asking the new Mayor of London whether he wishes to revoke the previous Mayor's support for the scheme.  Based on a discussion with officials (12th July) the SofS was strongly of the view that DfT must hold TfL to the agreement that they (TfL) pay all cost overruns.  He indicated that if TfL took a London-centric approach to Croxley this must call into question the Mayor's aspirations to take over suburban rail services.  The scheme was formally handed over from Hertfordshire County Council to Transport for London / London Underground Ltd in November 2015 and delivery is currently mandated by directions from the Mayor of London (March and November 2015) which include a 100% pain/gain for TfL on any increase/decrease in the cost of the scheme.  Pending completion of a scope/cost review and completion of procurement (both being undertaken by TfL) construction is due to start in autumn 2016 and complete in 2020.  Officials will be discussing the implications of the cost increase with TfL and other stakeholders.

The detailed designer and contractor were awarded under the Collaborative Delivery Framework in July 2015 to maintain programme and start works once the decision is made on the DCo submission.  The contractor was asked to re-assess the DCO construction programme and review the benefits of changing this to shorten the construction period and the traffic managment lengths thereby improving the impacts on the travelling public. This work was carried out and programme 2A is considered the best option which shortens the construction period to 50 months and proposes to use a greater number of shorter length and duration traffic management to address customer concerns regarding long lengths of traffic management. MOT Phase B delivery progress is on track in terms of spend delivery and quality. Velocity and vendor performance are consistent across all workstreams and are showing a gradual increase. The project is delivering value in the form of working software released to Live multiple times each sprint across application database infrastructure and data quality. Over 130 releases to Live have been made since the legacy MOT1 service was retired in late September 2015. A recent peer review by GDS described MOT Phase B as 'an exemplar of how to run a proper agile project' and 'one of the best agile projects we have seen in flight in government to-date' Project delivery improvement has been supported by the new Agile Governance work (commenced in January 2016). The MVP (Minimum Viable Product) of this framework is now in place on MOT delivering improved controls and assurance artefacts around agile process and software delivery including delivery roadmap (replacing legacy waterfall project plans) spend tracker (tracking spend for all vendors across all teams and workstreams sprint by sprint) and release plans covering releases of software to Live. The project continued to make good progress during Quarter 1 2016/17 in delivering further enhancements to the new MOT Testing Service application. Key service improvements included delivering functionality to support the rollout of the MOT Training Education and Skills Support (MTESS) service capabilities to support CPMS robustness and SPMS ( Slot Purchase management system) users and development of limited 2-Factor Authentication for early testing with users. Alongside the delivered application improvements the project has continued to refine its service design process to ensure that new features are based on insights from data and are researched and tested with users before development starts. The team has also made good progress in reducing defects by conducting more in-Sprint testing in the development environments enabling early identification and resolution by developers prior to promotion for release. The Common Payments (CPMS) team delivered the robustness features which will improve the communication between MOT and CPMS reducing the timescales for direct debit delivery.  The CPMS code base used by MOT and OLCS are being merged and tested to deliver a single code base reducing the total cost of ownership. The WebOps team have delivered resiliency capability and infrastructure streamlining is reducing the complexity of the architecture and lowering the cost. The move from SkyScape continues with further decommissioning saving £15k/month in costs a number of data quality changes have been deployed to improve the quality of the data available to the garages including 13k duplicate vehicles de-duped 28k incorrect expiry dates corrected 13k links between DVLA and DVSA data repaired which will ensure that Cherished Transfers of these vehicles will be correctly processed.

NR's overarching disposals strategy was endorsed by BICC in March. Since then NR has undertaken extensive and detailed work to assess the  asset classes in Plan A of the strategy - which were estimated to have potential to release £1.8bn of Public Sector Net Borrowing (deficit reducing receipts net of costs and taxes). NR's team have worked tirelessly to review all options and develop Business Cases. Analysis to date illustrates how difficult it will be to structure a transactions in a way that works for the stringent ESA 10 rules governing PSNB while protecting the operational railway and delivering value for money. NR has forecasted it will be very challenginge to score more than £300m PSNB proceeds in CP5
NR's next steps to address this potential shortfall in receipts will include: progressing work on the business cases for assets within Plan A

putting the first batch of SOBCs to its Property Board in July for endorsement. NR's project teams will recommend progressing work with a view to carving out any assets and transactions that can score for PSNB (as well as protecting the railway and delivering value for money)

considering options for raising cash (e.g. PSND debt reducing proceeds) where PNSB is not achieveable. A relaxation of the accounting requirements would make it possible to raise proceeds through more flexible deal structures such as leases which would enable them to manage operational interfaces
accelerating work on other potential transactions for station retail assets. At present DFT are supporting NR to scope the scale of proceeds NR could achieve from this option

NR will update BICC 18 July on asset disposals (and enhancements).  NR's Board will be reviewing the overall net position in relation to Hendy OMR and Asset Disposals in September before bringing forward its plans for managing delivery and pressures. NR will return to BICC in autumn (ahead of any fiscal event).
